title: Geared Desk Clock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A neat looking 3d printed gear clock for your desk!

You'll need to print:

  • 6x spacers
  • 3x 10 tooth gears
  • 2x 20 tooth gears
  • 2x 18 tooth gears
  • 2x 12 tooth gears
  • 1x 15 tooth gear
  • 2x foot
  • 1x 36 tooth "minute hand" gear
  • 1x 32 tooth "hour hand" gear
  • 1x 12 tooth motor gear
  • 1x motor mount
  • 1x plate

Additionally:

  • 12x nylon washers
  • 8x m4 20mm bolts
  • 8x m4 nuts
  • 6x m4 13mm standoffs round
  • 1x stepper motor (I recommend model 28BYJ-48)
  • 1x stepper motor driving board
  • (Optional) 1x small magnet
  • (Optional) 1x reed switch
  • glue (Super glue works, but I recommend a solvent based glue like "Weld-On 16")

Tools:

  • Screw Driver
  • Pliers
  • Small File

Assembly:

  1. Print all the parts.
  2. Glue together gear sets as specified in ascii_gearsets.txt
    • Note! Don't glue to the metal standoff or to the nylon washer.
  3. Attach the motor using the motormount and its corresponding 12 tooth gear.
    • Note! Put a nylon washer between the gear and the plate.
    • Note! You can mount the motor from the front or from behind, pick your favorite.
  4. Screw the clock face to the plate as shown in the pictures.
    • Note! Don't pinch the nylon washer between metal standoff and the plate.
  5. Screw the remaining gear sets to the plate.
  6. Push the feet into place.
  7. Attach power, and make the motor run at 3 revolutions per hour.
  8. Done!

Optional:

  1. Mount the reed switch so it is triggered by the magnet.
  2. Write code to adjust your motor speed when the reed switch is triggered.
  3. Make sure reed switch is triggered once every 12 hours.

Tips:

  • Depending on your printer you may need to size up or down the gears by 1%.
  • Additionally you may want to file the mounting holes for the gears.
  • You want a nice frictionless rotation of all gears around the standoffs and with each other.

Where to get stuff:

  • Nylon Washers - http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/Keystone-Electronics/3138
  • Standoffs - http://www.mouser.com/ProductDetail/RAF-Electronic-Hardware/M0542-4-SS/
  • Motors - https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B01CP18J4A/
  • Glue - https://smile.amazon.com/dp/B0149IFA9O
  • Magnets - https://www.kjmagnetics.com/proddetail.asp?prod=D41-N52

Helpful resources:

  • Gear train generator - http://geargenerator.com
    • The gear train for this clock - http://bit.ly/2irquMW
  • Gear train calculator - http://scientific601.altervista.org/gear/gearcalc.html

FAQ:

  • I see a circuit board and code in your pictures, can I have their source?
    • Not at this time, sorry.
  • What was this designed with?
    • Autodesk Fusion 360.

Printer:

MP Select Mini

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.20mm

Infill:

70%

Notes:
  • Works great in PLA or PETG.
  • Make sure the parts are flat and not warped after printing.

comments.author: allObjects

comments.text: Awesome rearrangement of the gears! Do you have a picture of how that looks?
comments.author: allObjects

comments.text: not yet... so far have just the gears and understand how they work... was actually the second time I used my 3d printer after just get it assembled and printing some tries, like the famous boad with lego bottom and chimney and a dog for on of my grand kids. I still have to come up with the spacers that are as thick as the gears. Furthermore, the rearrangement of the gears may change the motor mounting as well, because the minute gear is not on bottom level anymore, but one level up. ...may be I'm ending up with a remix... my final goal is to use it (with a second motor) to build an oversized Swiss Railway Clock - as designed not only visually but behaviorally by Swiss Engineer Hans Hilfiker in 1944. The most unique part is that the second hand runs a round in about 58.5 seconds, stops for 1.5 second at top, and then the minut hand jumps to the next minute and at the same time the second hand begins a next round. This behavior was due to the then available technology which sent nation wide a pulse every minute by the master clock... the second hand was driven by a local independent, synchron motor of the power grid frequency (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swiss_railway_clock). The software will be very simple due to the use of Espruino: a few lines of standard JavaScript.
comments.author: kobaj

title: Resyringe -  The Retractable, Refillable, High-Torque Compact Direct-Drive Paste Extruder

description.text:
This project has not been abandoned! I have been focusing on tuning up my printer and tweaking the code for my other Thing (which in turn will provide a hyperbolic gearset with an optimized ratio). My biggest roadblock has been actually printing extra parts for further testing, as my printer has recently been in and out of commission. I have plenty of filament to throw at it though.

Finalizing v0.2 models for upload! Stress testing has also been completed; I will upload the images and details.

I'm currently working on my printer's bridging capabilities, so I won't be able to make any bridging related improvements until that's finished.

One thing I do need help with is printing with chocolate; I need to know what the most popular heating solutions are so that I can provide support for them in this design.

Hardware:

2x 608zz skate bearings
1x 6-8mm M3 screw
7x 8-10mm M3 screws (swap one for 10-12mm if using a vertical mount)
7x M3 nuts
1x M5 screw, 10mm-25mm
1x M8 nut
1x M8 threaded rod or long screw (about 120mm)
Stepper motor
Syringe (10mL centre slip or Luer lock)

Support removal

There are built-in supports in some of the current models to take care of the overhangs and bridging. They should be only 1-2 walls thick; cut them with a hobby knife if they are stubborn.

When I was looking into the future possibility of building a paste printer, I found that the other paste extruders here didn't quite fit my needs. I was looking for something that was easy to clean (direct-drive syringe-based), could handle thicker material, and could also handle retraction. The only options I found were either too weak, unable to retract, or were Bowden-style.
So, I came up with some ideas, and just as quickly saw their flaws. That was, until I thought about doing the opposite of a lead screw: turn the nut to move the screw.
The first idea from this was to print a new plunger with built in threads, and mate it to a printed gear. Then I realized that I had an M8 rod at my disposal, and that eventually led to this.
Shortly afterward, I realized that I needed some way to transfer the motion of a stepper to the nut on the thread. I figured that a worm gear would put it in the best possible position, and I just so happened to remember seeing the hyperbolic gear now used in the design.

TODO:

Fix non-manifold file(s)
Design top assembly with endstop mount
Images of the assembled model
Final tests w/o printer frame
Calculate average steps/mm from tests

Version 0.1 (current)

First revisions uploaded to Thingiverse.
Quick-release mounts integrated into design.
Initial testing of printed components.

Version 0.2 (unfinished)

Improved design based on real-world testing.
Simpler part trees in FCSTD files.

Next Up

v0.3: Out-of-material switch mounts and actual part names
v0.4: Heater pad support for chocolate printing
v0.5: Complete documentation, including building instructions and a usage manual

title: WanHao Dial Gage Mount for front fan bracket

description.text:
update 2-5-17
Did not like the difference of offset from nozzle to measuring point, so I have updated the dial gage holder. I can now reach all but the last 25mm or so of the bed.

I drilled the fan mount for the front to accept the dial gage rod, and made this holder to keep the dial gage mounted securely. Had to add a tip extender to get the tiny little bit more reach needed. This ended up being a good thing as it can be removed and the dial gage now stays out of the way when printing if you want it mounted all the time.

Scad Files included as slight modifications will be needed depending on the hole you drill :) have fun!

--First 2 pictures show the differences of the 2 styles of mounts--
--left original holder files for those who are ok with the offset and not wanting to drill their fan mount--

Since mounting my fan behind the X-Axis carriage with this fan duct ( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1621937 ), I decided that my Dial Gage could use the holes left over from the front fan bracket as a place for a solid mount - easy to see too!

Use a 5mm x 20mm bolt and lock nut to hold the Dial Gage to this bracket.
Use 3mm x 5mm to hold this to the fan location.
This should allow you to move the x and y axis' and easily see the numbers.

Version 4 has been rotated and has a split mount for holding the dial gage better.
there is a hole for the bolt - but it held tight enough with friction - so a bolt might not be required
OpenSCAD Files included because that is how I am learning to use OpenSCAD :)

title: Monoprice Select Mini M5 Lead Screw Mod

description.text:
The original lead screw and stepper motor combo on the MPSM create rounding errors in height calculations and require odd layer heights. Any other lead screw with a nema 17 would have given even numbers. The M5 commonly used on the Prusa i3 gives even step values on any even number and fraction. Replacing the stepper requires drilling holes in the frame but wasn't that difficult. You can keep the old stepper and it will give you much better values on 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 mm layer heights but it still won't be perfect.

For this mod you will need to print the coupler and lead screw nut.

I made the coupler using the customizer:

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1329750
Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=1329750

I didn't design the lead screw nut ,however I did change the name to reflect what we are using it for here. The holes line up perfectly with the original nut holder. The original design is by av8r1: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1959596

The lead screw is standard 5mm threaded rod, 0.8mm pitch.

comments.text: How much difference have you noticed in your prints once you installed this?
comments.author: cwarts

comments.text: I noticed some improvement. The reason I did it was that I had some m5 rod around from a prusa build and was tired of doing the "ideal layer" height calculations with the stock lead screw and stepper. The m5 screw with a nema 17 stepper does even layer heights in multiples of 0.1mm.
comments.author: cwarts

comments.text: Do you think the Z carriage would accept a Delrin brass nut for a TR8*8 metric leadscrew?
comments.author: Sean_c_roberts

remixed_from.title: MP Select Mini 75mm VESA front mount bracket

title: MPSM Filter Bar + Front VESA Bracket Remix

description.text:
I liked the filter bar mount by jasonjones and when it came time to figure out how to put a VESA mount on the front of the MPSM, I realized I had a conflict. I found the remix by mrevans which I liked and also the VESA mount remix by alexisgreen but neither suited my needs. I also wanted the base of the filter affixed to to the part and set to the proper height to feed right into the extruder as all the existing designs had the filter a bit low, even when affixed with mounting tape.

You'll want to print with supports and this uses the filter that is hinged by a piece of 1.75 mm filament.

I remixed this in TinkerCAD as "MPSM Combined Filter and Front Vesa Mount" and made it publicly available if you want to modify it further. This is designed for the stock extruder bracket, If you've replaced with one of the aluminum extruder kits extruder mounts, you might want to tweak the alignment of the filter to the intake hole.

This is my first remix so comments are welcome.

comments.text: I modeled a version of this that puts the VESA support straight out the side.  That way there is no need for all of the support under the mount during print.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

title: Mini ITX Computer Case - Modular / Stackable

description.text:
This is a project I have been working on for some time. It is the original purpose for which I bought a 3D printer and is finally coming to fruition. This design will require onboard power or pico-PSU style power supplies, for now.

Project Goals:
Modularity - Inspired by Legos
Stackable - Each self-contained module can be stacked in a tower
Minimalistic - Small footprint, as little wasted inner space as possible
Print-ability - No supports, little waste, low warp risk
Marketability - Anyone interested?

There are two version to choose from:
The slim version is for Slim-ITX boards and does not allow space for hard drives.
The standard version should fit any ITX board and has space for two hard drives with the included bracket.

Future Plans:
I'd like to add modules to hold various PSU and VGA cards. This will enable this case to be used for a gaming or desktop style system. If anyone would like customization, please message me.

Additions:
3.5 inch Hard Drive Module (currently untested, 1/27/17)

Printer Brand:

Robo 3D

Printer:

R1 ABS + PLA Model

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10%

Notes:

I have designed this project around a 0.4mm nozzle and 0.2mm layer height. For best results, print at or below that resolution. I used an average infill of 10%, more can be used if you choose. Some light cleanup should be all you need post-print.

ITX Stacker - Top or Bottom:
This part caps off the top or bottom of the case. It will require excellent bed adhesion and a brim is recommended. Estimated weight: 47g

ITX Stacker - MB Tab Lock:
These tabs are screwed down to lock the motherboard in place with normal case screws. No brim needed. Estimated weight: 0.15g

ITX Stacker - Flange:
The flange is designed to be an optional spacer between systems when stacking. It will require excellent bed adhesion and a brim is recommended. Estimated weight: 20g

ITX Stacker Slim - Back Blank Panel:
This panel can be used as is or for making custom I/O ports. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Slim - Back Panel with Wifi:
This version includes a mount hole for a wifi antenna. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Slim - Back Plate Corner:
This corner differs from the universal corner in that it has space cut out to allow for the I/O panel to fit into the back panel. I recommend this be printed with three universal corners. Face their inner areas towards each other and set layer start to nearest. This will keep the visible surface clean and pit free. Estimated weight: 2g

ITX Stacker Slim - Front Blank Panel:
This panel can be used as is or for making custom I/O ports. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish. Estimated weight: 15g

ITX Stacker Slim - Front Panel with Power and LED:
This panel I have customized for a small power button and LED. The area over the LED is only 0.2mm thick to allow for the light to bleed through, yet invisible when off. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish. Estimated weight: 15g

ITX Stacker Slim - Single Fan Panel:
This panel includes a mount point for a single 40mm fan. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish. Estimated weight: 14g

ITX Stacker Slim - Universal Corner:
This corner is to be used on any of the corners except the one the back plate I/O panel cuts into. I recommend this be printed as a set of four with a back plate corner. Face their inner areas towards each other and set layer start to nearest. This will keep the visible surface clean and pit free. Estimated weight: 2.5g

ITX Stacker Slim - Vent Panel:
This panel has vents for airflow into or out of the stack. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish. Estimated weight: 13g

ITX Stacker Standard - Back Blank Panel:
This panel can be used as is or for making custom I/O ports. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Standard - Back Panel with Wifi:
This version includes a mount hole for a wifi antenna. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Standard - Back Plate Corner:
This corner differs from the universal corner in that it has space cut out to allow for the I/O panel to fit into the back panel. I recommend this be printed with three universal corners. Face their inner areas towards each other and set layer start to nearest. This will keep the visible surface clean and pit free.

ITX Stacker Standard - Dual Fan Panel:
This panel includes a mount point for two 40mm fans. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Standard - Front Blank Panel:
This panel can be used as is or for making custom I/O ports. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Standard - Front Panel with Power:
This panel I have customized for a 16mm anti-vandal power switch. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

ITX Stacker Standard - Hard Drive Bracket:
This bracket is mounted to the bottom of the motherboard and has space for two 2.5 inch hard drives (currently untested).

ITX Stacker Standard - Universal Corner:
This corner is to be used on any of the corners except the one the back plate I/O panel cuts into. I recommend this be printed as a set of four with a back plate corner. Face their inner areas towards each other and set layer start to nearest. This will keep the visible surface clean and pit free.

ITX Stacker Standard - Vent Panel:
This panel has vents for airflow into or out of the stack. Print face down; bed surface will determine a matte or shinny finish.

To create one "module" you will need three universal corners, one back plate corner, and a combination of the four side panels. The fan panel and vent panels can be swapped and doubled up, should you choose a passively cooled or intake/outtake fan setup.

Multiple modules can be stacked up to accommodate the number of systems you have. The flange can be used optionally to visually separate the modules. The top or bottom part only needs to be printed twice, as any expansion will only increase the height of the stack.

All modules in the stack are bound together with #10-32 threaded rods. These are cut to length with a cap nut on each side. The rods will only need to be recut if more modules are added to the stack.

Glue may also be used between the corner and side panel joints for extra rigidity, but not necessary.

description.text: BEFORE PRINTING BE AWARE THE PCB IN THIS DESIGN IS CUSTOM AND DIFFERENT FROM ADAFRUITS IT IS MADE FOR THE SOFT TACTILE BUTTONS. THE GERBER FILE PROVIDED IS ONLY THE BOTTOM COPPER OF THE PCB, YOU CAN USE A PROGRAM CALLED GERBV TO VIEW AND PRINT THE PCB DESIGN. I USED PRESENSITIZED PCBS FOR THIS. I build the original pigrrl 2 handheld and found the feel of the buttons wrong. Too close together and too noisy. Mind you I didn't use flexible filament, anyway I came up with this design using button guides, 4 separated buttons and soft tactile switches. I also had to redesign the circuit board. Gerber file included. the feel is way nicer and much more playable. I also wanted a larger screen such as the 3.5 inch display but the gpio screens are too laggy. I went with a 3.5inch composite display and I made it fit into the top case without using a lot of glue to hold it there. I found a barrel battery holder for a li-ion battery fits nicely in the bottom case without it moving around, battery life isn't that great so maybe in the future i can put two batteries in there.

description.text:
These files are a for the board mount and compact controller holder.

The lasercut case that comes with the filastruder kit is too bulky especially for a vertically mounted filastruder. Verically mounted, the feed is more difficult, and sufficient plastic pellet flow nearly impossible to do with the bulky stock case.

These file are for a control panel, switch and fan mount. They copy the geometry of the laser cut parts some, except the fan is side mounted.

Also included is a back mount for the current / voltage limiting board. There board mount is screwed into the motor case with the printed plastic 'bolts' included in the file.

Next I will be making a hopper for my vertically mounted filastruder.

This is still very much a WORK IN PROGRESS I would appreciate and tips or ideas, if you print it tell me how it goes. (I tried to make it as printer friendly as possible) good luck :)

PS: put a needle in the tiny hole in the arm that swings.

I'm mounting a laser pointer on my left z-axis housing, and a target on my right z-axis housing, so that I can easily see when they get out of alignment with each other.

The actual laser pointers are a buck each on ebay:
http://www.ebay.com.au/itm/1pcs-LED-Light-Laser-Pointer-Funny-Cat-Rod-Laser-pet-Cat-free-shipping-/112270606961?hash=item1a23d98271:g:RPQAAOSwZQRYfC~Z

This gives direct feedback when the two Z-axis steppers get out of sync with each other - which happens surprisingly often. When they are not in sync, there is no point calibrating your print bed - with the laser pointer, you find that often the bed hasn't shifted at all, and realigning the two z-axis steppers is a relatively quick and easy process, so hopefully this constitutes a real upgrade to the problem of constant recalibrations of the print bed adjustment screws.

Update: Back to the drawing board! The problem with this design is that the laser just points along the Y-axis, even when the Z-steppers are out of alignment. But I have a Plan-B. I need to mount the laser pointer onto the main frame of the A6, and direct the laser through targets on both Z-axis idler boxes. Stay posted for something that works coming soon....

description.text:
I love my bluetooth mouse from Amazon. My 20 month old daughter got ahold of it and somehow got the battery cover off, and it is now missing. Knowing her, she probably put it in the trash. She loves putting stuff in the trash.

So... now I can use my 3D Printer for USEFUL stuff, instead of trinkets :)

Took 6 tries to get it right. Just measuring with a micrometer, and getting the tabs to work properly.

This is my first truly useful 3D print, other than mods for the Anet. Pretty proud of it. I have quite a few other things missing battery covers, so I see a trend in what I'll be posting on Thingiverse :)

This is the mouse on Amazon:
https://www.amazon.com/Multimedia-Connectland-CL-MOU23014-Bluetooth-Wireless/dp/B005UFDRWI/

I'm sure it is sold under different brand names. This may fit other mice too. The measurements are 48mm x 17.5mm x 2mm.

Printer:

Anet A8-B

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.20

Infill:

15% rectangular

Notes:

The tabs may be a bit tricky. I use Simplify 3D, and here is what I did:

2 Processes.

1st Process starts from bottom and goes to 2mm:
2 Solid layers top and bottom
1 Outline/Perimeter Shell
Rectangular infill 15%.
1800mm/min max speed (under advanced tab, need a nice and slow print)
Extrusion Multiplier 1.07
Outline underspeed 50%

2nd Process starts at 2mm, and is exactly the same as the process above, with the exception of the exterior fill pattern being concentric. This is mainly due to me not being able to get the fill rate right to make them strong. If your settings are spot on, and you get a truly 100% fill layer on the tabs you probably won't need the 2nd process. The concentric fill just seems a little stronger, but makes the rest of the cover look ugly so I kept the first 2mm rectangular.

You may have to trim the tab on the first layer if you have some drooping. Just take a razor blade and trim it so it's a square flush line, otherwise it won't fit.

Tab before trimming. Stringy.
Autodesk 123D, lots of trial and error (I'm still a newbie)

description.text:
Was inspired by the various vase mode spiral prints I saw on this website, and decided to design my own! The form comes from a square extruded vertically with a 180 degree twist.

Filament I used was AMZ3D Wood Filament.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

Vase Mode

Notes:

Relevant Settings:
Vase Mode Enabled (Called single outline corkscrew printing mode in Simplify3D)
Nozzle Height: 0.2mm
Nozzle Extrusion Width: 0.52mm (Slightly fatter to allow more adhesion surface area)

These two settings will decide if your print stays open or closed. Since I printed this to be used as a lampshade I left both to 0 so I got an open formed print.
Bottom Solid Layers: 0
Top Solid Layers: 0

Brim: 3 skirt outlines (just a precautionary measure, since this print is hollow, there is very little surface area between the first layer and the build surface. May lead to your print pulling off your plate before it is finished printing.
Modeled in Rhino with Grasshopper.

title: 4 char idioms - stereographic projection
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
As I said in Stereographic projection maze, I hit upon a great idea one day. If we waive the maze algorithm aside, there exists an easy way to perform a stereographic projection in OpenSCAD.

I wrote a stereographic_projection which can perform stereographic projection on 2D objects. The customizer here is just a demonstration. If stereographic_projection interests you, you may find it in "chinese_4_char_idioms.scad". The stereographic_projection itself has only about twenty lines.

The chinese_4_char_idioms module is designed specifically for traditional-Chinese characters with the font "微軟正黑體". If you want to use other characters and their respective fonts, the chinese_4_char_idioms module could be a template.

Find my things about stereographic projection in stereographic_projection.

  • OpenSCAD Documentation - Traditional Chinese
  • OpenSCAD Documentation - English

Printer:

CR8

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

layer 0.25 mm

Infill:

100%

My library dotSCAD has a stereographic_extrude module. You can use it to create a thing of stereographic projection easily.

  • stereographic_extrude

A small box with a slot for the hundreds of colors and materials from Rosco film gel swatches, 1.5" X 2.5" . It needs a short piece of LED strip, disk type G4(s), or LED module(s) mounted in the bottom.
Modeled and STL exported >DIRECTLY TO 3DHUBS< with 3DOrchard beta.
Use multiple gels together for infinity colors.
The LED color could be 4,000K to 7,000K for the best reproduction of the gel color, but to duplicate regular film lighting, use 2800 Kelvin lights http://www.lilyleds.com/9538/G4-LED-Bulb-12-LEDs-Side-Pins
The other LED G4 is a single light point CREE, for crisp shadows.

Patrick at https://www.3dhubs.com/service/Scramjet did a nice printing job again.
Flashforge Dreamer with black PLA He thickened the back wall on http://www.3DOrchard.com before printing it. No more sending attachments and all that.

I made tolerances a bit tight, print about 2% bigger or you'll have to cut the gel.
Seriously, am I the only one getting this stuff printed?

author: sleepybishop

description.text:
Here is my re-mix on the F.Tobler robot arms. Most of the files are the same that that from Tobler. I only attached the new parts here. Below are the changes that I made:-

  1. Better wiring on hiding the motor cable.
  2. Fit the mini-stepper motor board inside the lower shank.
  3. Change the endstop plate to endstop with home switches.
  4. 2 home switches added as shown for upper & lower shank.
  5. Add cables outlet under the new endstop module.
  6. A new RAMPS case made with 5cm PC Fan.
  7. Tie gripper motor input from 5V to 12V to improve response. (new)
  8. Modify the gripper fingers for holding pen and marble. (new)

Demo:
https://youtu.be/V9V-t0cJFI8 (new)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HXhPVoDxrdw
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=j5DSirqxDHk

title: BBC Marconi-Reisz Microphone
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I modeled this after the type of microphone used by the BBC in the 20's to late 30's. Once you print it off, take an old telephone handset and take the microphone out of it, run some wires through the back of it, connect them to the microphone, and put the microphone in the case with some padding. Put a piece of fabric between the case and the cover, so the microphone doesn't pop out, and for decorative purposes.The electronic part of this could be improved upon greatly, but it suits my needs just fine.

Scale it up to around 10, since inventor sucks with exporting the correct sized stl files.

title: NEMA 11 motor plate OFFSET heat shield - 3mm thick

description.text:
This is an add-on for a flying extruder using a NEMA 11 motor. This offset plate shield helps protect the actual extruder body (if printed in normal PLA/ABS) from the immense heat of the motor as it runs! [esp. during long prints]

It CAN and WILL soften/melt your extruder body without a shield of some kind. Covering the body is kapton tape can help, but isn't as glamorous as a custom-built heat shield.

author: Paultini

print_settings.Notes:: Make sure you use high infill for strength, I recommend a bare MINIMUM of 35%.  More infill is better.

title: MendelMax Vertical X Axis Ends & Carriage

description.text:
After fighting with the lack of Z height caused by my hacked addition of an E3D Titan and E3D Lite6 hot end to my MendelMax, I thought to try a vertical X axis, to hopefully move the Titan's filament feed slightly rearward and gain some Z volume on the printer.

Not finding any that were complete, or that didn't require extensive (re)work, I decided to make my own. Surprisingly, it came together and worked perfectly. So now, I share the working design with you!

Technical Details

The Z axis bearing and lead screw mounts are designed for 8mm shafts, and four-screw flanges for attachment. LMK8LUU bearings should work well here, as well as TR8 eBay leadscrews with flanged nuts.

The rod distances (30mm smooth/leadscrew for Z, and 50mm smooth/smooth for X) are the same as in the "standard" Mendel design and do not require customized motor mounts or upper vertex rod stays.

Speaking of the rods, both X and Z are 8mm.

You likely will need a longer belt for the X axis. I've changed X axis parts often enough that I don't actually remember if a stock one will fit.

The X carriage itself has holes designed to securely hold a metal NEMA 17 motor mount. These work well for mounting Titan extruders.

There is no provision for mounting an X axis end stop switch. I'm re-using my normal one for this experiment.

I consider this modification to be very experimental due to its nature. So, caveat emptor, and your mileage may vary.

Bonus

For Z, I have included an end stop screw mount that attaches to the X carriage's 8mm rods. It's designed to hit this Z end stop mount:

XYZ End Stops for Mendelmax 1.5+

Come to think of it, this will work with the 10mm rod version of these carriages, too!

Attribution

I used:

  • the "roundedRect" OpenSCAD module by WilliamAAdams
  • the excellent zip-tie LM8UU bearing holder by skarab

I've added them as remixes on the side, and attributed them in the included source code for the parts. You will need skarab's STL file in order to fully render my SCAD source, and you will need to change the file path in the source to point at your version.

Printer Brand:

Solidoodle

Printer:

Solidoodle 4

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2963mm

Notes:

I used Prusa's fork of Slic3r, with no supports or rafts, and an imperial threaded rod's unfortunate layer height. Printed on the Solidoodle 4 because I prefer to use ABS for these kind of parts.

Make sure you use high infill for strength, I recommend a bare MINIMUM of 35%. More infill is better.

All

  • Save for the M5 screw on the idler carriage, the rest of the carriages use M3 hardware to secure everything. I used 10mm M3-0.5 cap head screws for the bulk of the assembly, with 16mm screws and nuts for the X belt and [planned for] TR8 flanged nuts.

End Carriages

  • The larger load-bearing holes are printed horizontally: expect to clean up artifacts from bridging and overhang sag if you print ABS at ~0.3mm layer heights.

  • I use a drill bit to gently ream out the 8mm rod holes. This gives me a gently snug fit and takes care of any overhang/bridging artifacts.

  • The holes for the LMK8LUU bearing flange are slightly undersized, so that screws can be screwed into the holes hand tight. These should be sufficient to hold the bearings in place.

Idler carriage

  • The idler pulley uses an M5 machine head screw, with an arrangement of nuts and washers to trap the idler pulley at the correct height, and a nut in the front of the idler assembly to snug the entire thing in place.

X carriage

  • The X carriage requires little to no prep. The nut catches on the underside are designed to have nuts sunken into them via a screw on the opposite side. I recommend a wide washer on said screw to prevent surface damage. This technique is best used with ABS, although PLA will trap nuts as well.

  • The TR8 flanged lead screw nuts are designed to be mounted using nuts on the M3 screws, for greater stability.
Designed using OpenSCAD (www.openscad.org)

PEI on a heated bed has amazing adhesion when heated and allows the finish like a glass bed and prints come off much easier than blue tape when the bed is cooled.

A clip to hold down your PEI bed. You need to have a glass bed underneath this to fit correctly. Why glass + PEI? Initially, I was going to only go with glass but I had inconsistent adhesion issues with glass but wanted a flat strong surface and the finish of the glass. PEI needs a flat surface and the aluminum bed can warp.

Requires:
(3/32) inch thick glass = 2.38125mm
.03 inch thick PEI sheet = .762mm
PEI sheet - https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0013HKZTA/ref=biss_dp_t_asn
This is a 12 x 12 (300x300mm) which can be cut into fourths

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kpfQEeMkOAO

author: JackDavies

description.text:
Introduction.

This is a method for quickly getting a good backlash calibration on your 3D printer.
You just zero out the backlash compensation in the software. Then print the objects, Read the correct value and enter it as your new backlash compensation and be done with it.

The files have been created with the M3D Micro in mind but should work for all 3D printers of the Cartesian type. It will not work for delta printers.

Instruction.

Before getting started on this, you need to make sure your print bed is clean and very well
calibrated. The print is just a single layer and it needs to be printed just right across the entire surface. You can find more information about bed leveling below.

Before starting the first print make sure to set backlash compensation to zero. Make a note of the old values in case you need to go back.
Watch the print start and remove the extra filament that is extruded in the beginning. It is just to prime the nozzle.
The included files will make 200 samples. You have to study these samples very very carefully. You have to find the sample with the highest possible value that does not curve. We are talking about a curve that only moves 0.01 mm to the side. It sounds impossible to spot. But it is actually doable. I recommend having a ruler in one hand and a flashlight in the other. You can also use a magnifying glass or take a good quality picture and then zoom in.
When you have located the correct sample, calculate the backlash value using the chart/picture above. I think it is a good idea to make three prints and take the average value spotted for each. If one of them is way off disregard it and make another. If in doubt choose the lower value.
Repeat for the other axis and enter the values you found in your printer software.

I encourage you to post an "I made one" with a photo to help other users get a hang of reading the result.

More knowledge.

Bed levelling

I generally like the automatic methods for calibration, like "Recalibrate Drive System" or "Run complete bed calibration". Note that these methods are very sensitive to disturbance. You shouldn't even walk near the printer while it is running unless you have a concrete floor. If the automatic method isn't good enough I like AidanHortons manual method for fine tuning the bed level:
http://www.thingiverse.com/groups/m3d-the-micro-3d-printer/topic:5062

Where in the software do I adjust it?

This article has some nice screenshots of how to adjust backlash in the M3D software:
https://printm3d.com/solutions/article.php?id=234
You need to set the values to 0 before using the Quick Backlash Calibration.

What is Backlash anyway?

I love how this simplified illustration explains the issue. The point of the calibration is to get to know how much the first cog has to move extra when the direction changes. We want to know this in a precision measured in hundreds of millimeters.
https://edinburghhacklab.com/wp-content/uploads/2013/04/backlash.gif
There are of course more to it than a single gear connection. There are more gears and belts with slack as well. But the moving picture illustrates the problem well.

Version 2?

Compared to version 1 I doubled the number of samples to reduce the complexity when getting started on this and improved tolerance towards poor bed leveling. Other than that the files are identical. If you are having success with version 1 you will have no benefit in changing to version 2.
Version 1 is here if you are curious: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1435828

comments.text: Everybody in the RC hobby has a universal charger that can charge almost any chemistry battery, including Li-ion. This gives an almost 0 cost solution to mate this battery to those chargers. Alternatively, if you are working on a circuit powered by a single Li-ion cell, this allows you to easily connect it for testing purposes.

print_settings.Printer:: R1 ABS + PLA Model

description.text:
Here's my collection of files to print my giant minifig collection.

There are 22 figures in all. All of them have accessories except the 2 'limited edition' even larger format figures (Hulk & Carbonite Han Solo).

These are (obviously) based on Skimbal's work, along with many others. That said, I've modified well above 70% of them to print better (in one way or another). There are also unique designs I did myself (such as Aquaman & many of the accessories).

'big_base.stl' included since thingiverse requires at least one STL file per thing. The rest of the files (and there are many) are in the included ZIP file.

All were printed on my Robo3D R1 in PLA at .2mm Z resolution with a .4mm nozzle. Many are optimized for exactly that size.

AVA's Uncle Les has another idea for play toys: resettable dominos. Isn't it a drag that when you set up a chain of dominos to be toppled, they topple themselves at the slightest touch, and they only work once?

That's where these designs change things. Version 1 has a hinged base for gluing with glue stick down to a base, and Version 2 tries to stay up by being bottom heavy and curvy. So you set up your dominos and can topple them again and again!

These designs are untested. Version 1 looks like it is close to working properly, and Version 2 kinda topples over by itself, lol.

Note that prior art on the subject can be found in this patent:
https://www.google.com/patents/US20100173557
which uses a track to hold the dominos in alignment.

title: Tank3d printer
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Still in Alpha stage. Will be posting element by element and link here, so please subscribe, so you keep in touch with the latest development and updates

Join the new Support forum to discuss the printer in details and Tank3d Facebook Group for the latest news and quick Q&A

HI,
My name is Boyan. Here i present you a printer which i call Tank3d due to its shape and robustness. The printer design is a result of extensive research + my experience as a DIY machine builder and each element is designed from scratch by me exactly to serve its integral purpose in an optimal manner. The aim is to be the best performing Cartesian 3d printer while maintaining absolute simplicity and easy to DIY build

The main Purpose:

  1. 3d printer build from 20x20 aluminum extrusion that is fully scalable to at least 600x600x600mm without any further change than using longer rails and longer profiles for the frame.
  2. The printer to be able to achieve real life 150mm/sec printing speeds with acceleration at least 1500mm/s2, while producing high quality prints at that settings.
  3. A real production machine to be able to work non stop 24h for at least 5 years, minimum maintenance and no further adjustments, high precision and repeatability during its life cycle.
    4.Not exactly cheap to build but Best Bang For The Buck

Additional Purpose
While the ideal candidate for custom size order printer for you or your client, if by any reason you dont like the design, the elements can be used to make any printer, printer enclosures filament boxes, etc.

Design Details:
There is not a specific order of importance as all is equally important for a perfect final result. The whole is as strong as its weakest spot

Working area is X440 x Y220 x Z200mm .Outside enclosure dimensiones ~630x430x410 mm. Probably one of the best ratio of working area to oustide dimensions. Compromise between size, $$, ability to do very small parts precisely and at the same time have large volume area.

  1. Parts are designed as much as printable as possible. Material could be PLA for most parts except for parts around heated bed, provided that if when enclosed you monitor temperature and do not permit enclosure to heat more than 45C. ABS, Hi temp PLA, PTEG are other options.

  2. Parts are designed so that printer could be put together precisely square and all elements aligned extremely fast and easy. So an accurate machine could be build just using a simple square and digital caliper.

  3. All elements are housed inside the frame so an enclosure could be formed by just fitting panels outside

  4. Bed is heated aluminum plate 6mm 500w/230VAC

  5. Linear movement is HIWIN MGN12H on all axis. Belt is 10mm GT2 belt, puleys are 20T. Motors are low induction high power Wantai 10PCS Nema17 Step Motor 42BYGHW811 4800g.cm 2.5A 2Ph

  6. Motion control is Duet WIFi as at the moment is the only controller that could push reliably the motors to specified speeds and acceleration

to continue....

Not in Particular Order, All will be published together when out of Beta stage and stable V1.

Every single part is drawn from 0. Prototyped separately, tested for strength, printability, costs and finally aesthetics. In the case where is directly inspired from existing similar one, credits will be given in the relevant section.

  • Tank3d Drag Cable Chain
  • ACME 8mm Tr88-2p + Tr84-2p leadscrew nut / 4 and 2 start/
  • Triple corner 20x20 Aluminum extrusion frame parts
  • Bottom triple corner L+R 20x20 aluminum extrusion frame parts
  • Tank3D T corner A and B 20x20 aluminum profile
  • Tank3d Simple Corner 20x20 aluminum extrusion

    License and Copyright:
    While Open Source, in order to maintain the integrity of a top notch printer, design changes are undesired without prior consultation, so are the remixes, hence the licence type. If you do that, just follow individual element licences which will be more free but dont call your printer Tank3d , just give credit for the used elements

Credits:
List will be long. More were pure inspiration as i designed personally all major elements, Nevertheless i couldn't do it without investigating the designs. If you dont see yourself here and feel that you should be given credit, please contact me. Hats down to some of the designers as they saved me a lot of time.

title: Knight of Egypt w/ embedded support

description.text:
This remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1826018 is created for print w/o support. Head of the Anubis creates most problems for printing since its slicer generated support should be based on the surface of the figure that would require some post-processing with sandpaper or alike.
Two figures are printed at once - it has clear logic. But also they share added support model.
Updated: lines support better envelops the head.
01/17/2017 - update1 - support lines step is reduced from 1.5mm to 1.25mm to better match the supported figure. The support column wall thickness is made 0.5mm in all parts - fixed.
01/18/2017 - update2 - support lines envelop is rounded for better quality of the chap print. Support is made wider to reduce artifacts in newly supported location. Seems this is final variant, because update1 already shows satisfactory result with low post-processing.
01/21/2017 - removed less successful support models. Upd2 is left only.
05/01/2017 - uploaded single figure with support by request.

Printer:

JGAURORA Z - 605S

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

Layer 0.1 mm Nozzle 0.4 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The support model is designed with thin walls considering only one nozzle size - 0.4mm (the walls were specified as 0.5mm), which is printed as single shell in one pass.
Artifacts of print w/o slicer support are small and are all located on the back. They can be easily post-processed if required.

I'm using ABS for the chess set print, 250C, no fan, 20 sec per layer min (I setup Cura plugin to switch fan on at 50% during ears print since they are thin and may melt and lose their form). I used raft with 3 layers of print surface and 0.05mm gap between last raft layer and the model. Usual gap for PLA is 0.15mm, but it does not work for ABS at all - the model detaches from heatbed. While 0.05mm works very well for some sorts of ABS.

I choose 0.2mm for first layer of the model, but any other first layer over raft should work.

Remove the support model.
If ABS is used I would consider to use acetone for post-processing of the whole chess set.
I used well known 'import' keyword in OpenSCAD and other embedded primitives of OpenSCAD.

description.text:
A cup with a snap-on, ventilated lid.  I'm using this to hold baking soda for absorbing fridge smells.  It could be used as a herb shaker too, if you made it foodsafe.
You may ask, "Why not just put a box of baking soda in the fridge?".  Shame on you!

Print and enjoy. The cup has an 84 mm outer diameter and an 82 mm inner diameter with a 1.6 mm thick bottom and a 42 mm total height. The lid has an 81 mm OD and an 80 mm ID and is 2 mm thick. The print time on my Thing-o-matic with default settings was about 15 minutes for the lid and about 90 minutes for the cup. If you regenerate the STL files from the 123D model, even with 123D's coarse setting, you'll probably have to run the meshes through MeshLab to reduce the polygon count (https://youtu.be/w_r-cT2jngk) and make them manifold (I don't know how to do that in MeshLab, I used http://cloud.netfabb.com, but MeshLab does it too I'm sure). If you try to use something like the 200,000-triangle lid that 123D Beta 9 produced for me it'll take forever to generate the gcode. The lid is made for a 0.5 mm nozzle. A 0.4 mm nozzle will leave a little gap in between lattice squares, and it will come apart very easily.

title: xyz daVinci Pro - Replacement Filament Feed Panel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It is a known issue with da Vinci 1.0 Pro printers that the small hole where the filament enters to engage the extruder gears gets worn down. Filament being pulled over a plastic corner tends to wear it away over time. @ChatToBrian covers this issue in this video where he discusses his external filament holder as well as the filament entry hole on the printer getting worn.

As you can see in my pictures I also have this wear issue. In addition to this, the first time I had to replace my Bowden tube fitting I broke one of the upper tabs on the little panel where the filament entry hole is. So, I decided to make a new panel to solve both issues.

I created two versions. One is basically a direct replacement for the stock panel with a chamfered hole to insert the filament through. I imagine this version will wear away at least as fast as the stock panel did, but perhaps will last longer if printed in nylon or another high-lubricity material.

The second version has a slightly larger hole that you can glue a short piece of PTFE tube in. I also provide a small cap for the other end of the PTFE tube to make it easier to feed filament into the tube. You can make the PTFE tube as long as you need. You could even try to incorporate the tube into an external spool holder similar to how Brian made his fix in his video.

description.text:
Just add two stacking containers, a tmer, a DC water pump fitted with a 7/16" I.D. hose, and you have a table top ebb and flow. Perfect for 4" rockwool or 5" net pots or similar sized grow bags.

This is developed for a small tabletop ikea container (ikea stock number: top:402.574.99 bottom: 802.574.97), or any containers that you can stack securely with a bottom reservoir. This is meant to be used with a small 5V-12V DC pump, with a 7/16" outer diameter hose. Drill two half inch holes, one for the water level drain, and another for hose from reservoir. Glue on hose retainer as shown in pictures.

The drain spacer is designed to be easily cut short if needed. Drain spacer and base and filter should all be friction fitted.

I'm taking some videos for details to be published later. Here's a video of how it works: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=A9V9XJSCxGI

Tips appreciated. Thanks,

Notes:

print the filter with a raft, pointy side up. The rest can all be printed with wide flat side on the print surface.

remixed_from.author: mangtronix
remixed_from.title: Tool to level X-axis of Prusa i3

description.text:
Same instructions as per the original posting BUT I will add that it would be best to print a matched pair so that 1 side doesn't try and adjust itself:

Customizable X-axis leveling tool designed for Prusa i3 Berlin. Used to make sure that each side of the X-axis is at the same height. Necessary since there's a stepper motor on each side and they can get out of step.
To use:
Place "forked" end of tool on Y smooth rod and use Z control to bring the X axis just above the flat part of the top of the tool. Manually rotate the Z rod for that side so the X carriage rod just touches the bottom of the "L" at the top of the tool. Adjust the other side the same way. Go back and forth to each side a few times to get the X-axis rod level.
IMPORTANT: Don't squish the tool between the rods by using the Z motor control - this could put pressure on the smooth rods and possibly bend them. Doing the final adjustment by hand works best.
I've been using this tool for awhile now and it works pretty well. One improvement would be if it had a hook to hang down from the X-axis rod instead of being squished between X-axis rod and Y-axis rod. Then you could hang one of the tools on each side of the X-axis rod and adjust them at the same time.

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280974

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=280974

UPDATE 18TH JAN 2017,
I have had to use these a few times already due to 1 reason or another and each time the results have been spot on and saves a lot of hassle by not having to measure the height of 1 side then the other and whilst adjusting 1 side the other side would also move. However with these everything is very clear and easy also having the 10cm height allows for universal use amongst many prusa style printers.

Using the following options:

rod_diameter = 8.2
beam_width = 10
beam_height = 10
claw_depth = 25
z_distance = 100
claw_height = 15
wall_thickness = 3

description.text:
After a long fight with my vacuum cleaners' hoses, I decided to make a thing which keeps them in position.
I wind up the hoses into small circles, but they keep unwinding themselves.

And here it is, the vacuum cleaner hose fix! Just wind up the hose, clip the thing in place, and no more problems!

Hope there are people whose problems will be solved by this revolutionary gadget :)

There are three versions:
DualHoseFix - Keep two hose-loops in position.
TriHoseFix (Codename "Biohazard") - For longer hoses with three loops.
QuadHoseFix (Codename "Drone") - For ludicurously long hoses, or keeping multiple hoses together, or playing ninja.

It works fine with PLA, but if that is too rigid for you, the more flexible ABS can also be good.
The thickness can be changed for more strength. I kept it as thin as possible to be able to clip into the hose.
The inner diameter for hose holders is 35mm.

description.text:
An object that creates different pixelated shadows depending on the lighting direction.

500 mm diameter Geodesic Dome

Desing considerations

The pieces are designed for a 3 mm diameter bar. It has a M3 screw to tight the upside and downside piece of each node.

The distance between the theorical vertex and the end of the bar is 7 mm, this distance is called Lhole in the fantastic dome calculator by SimplyDifferently.org

https://simplydifferently.org/Geodesic_Dome_Notes?page=3#2V/L2

In fact, you can change the diameter of the dome varying the long of the bars, feel free to play with this calculator.

If you need different bar diameter, you can scale the piece for a factor, you have to keep in mind that the diameter of the screw and the Lhole will be affected for the same factor.

Bill of materials:

20 pieces Hexagonal node
6 pieces Pentagonal node

Cut wood bars, I made from skewers

30 bars 123 mm
35 bars 141 mm

Screws

26 bolt M3x16 DIN912, nuts and washers.

How to assemble

1 - Assemble all the pentagonal nodes with all the shorter bars
2 - Join the 5-point stars with hexagonal nodes. The hexagonal nodes has a notch pointing to shorter bars.
3 - Now we can take longer bars and assemby with hexagonal nodes

See attached photos and floor plan.

Thanks

Based on the work of Effalo
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3215

But more specifically in the great labor of divulgation of Obijuan (In spanish)
https://github.com/TecnoLab/domocraft/wiki

title: Printable Fidget Cube
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Info

This is my version of a printable fidget Cube. It is fully printable excluding the five buttons.

Full credit for the Fidget Cube-idea goes to Antsy Labs (https://www.antsylabs.com/) who ran a very successful kickstarter campaign. My design is just loosely based on the real fidget cube and borrows other design ideas from similar designs uploaded here on thingiverse, including:

Twitch Block by MatterHackers (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1798009)
Fidget Cube by CThig (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1844556)
Fidget Cube replica by dudu_abdu (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1859311)

Please have a look at their designs as well!

Required Items

  1. A set of printed parts (See HowTo)
  2. Four 6 x 6 x 5mm tact switches (like these: https://goo.gl/QX8TDc)
  3. One 8.5 x 8.5mm latching push button (like these: https://goo.gl/PLje5V)
  4. Glue suitable for your filament of choice.

HowTo

  1. Print each of the three files. Cube and caps with 20% infill, no support, "things" (Buttons, wheel, etc.) with 50% infill, no support.
  2. Clean prints as best as possible by filing, sanding, etc. This is important, as there are some pretty steep overhangs in this design.
  3. Insert switches and buttons into their respective holes and cover with printed buttons. (Most probably you need to remove the pins/contacts from your buttons to make them fit)
  4. Use a piece of 1.75mm Filament as axle for the gear wheels. Push through from maze side to rocker-switch side of the cube.
  5. Push in the printed rocker switch
  6. Insert sliding knob into maze by pulling the maze cap slightly upwards

If all goes well (Test/break in all moving parts until they move freely) you should glue the six caps on to keep them in place.

Be careful not to glue any buttons/sliders in place permanently!

Have fun :D

description.text:
An Eachine QX90 Propeller Guard, designed with this particular quadcopter in mind, but could fit any 90mm frame using 8,5mm motors. The propeller guard can fit up to 62mm propeller diameter.

Lite edition - Lighter, faster

It is a revision of nightly revision 2, but significantly lighter.

-Frame reshaped
-Reduced hight of motor pylons
-Tightened inner diameter of motor pylons

Nightly Revision 2 - stronger, faster edition

Well at least stronger. I realised the previous version (now removed) had design flaws that are now corrected. More tanky

-Stronger struts
-Better adherence to motor pylons
-motor pylons slightly expanded (too tight a fit before)
-FPV field of view is now increased slightly, rounded corners are nicer for vision as well
-Stuts moved slightly down to allow for more propeller freedom
-Faster ... :)

description.text:
TDA7498E case for a cool amplifier

If you want to run this amp in mono like me you need to short the 4 BTL connections on the back of the board. Solder the J1,J2,J3 and J4 connections with a small wire.

Features:
Amplifier chip: original TDA7498E
Output power: 160W+160W (Vcc = 36 V, RL = 4Ω, THD: 10%)
Output power: 1x220W single channel in parallel BTL(Vcc = 36 V, RL = 3Ω, THD: 10%)
Support BTL mode (short J1, J2, J3, J4 located on the back of amplifier board)
Wide range single power supply: 15-36VDC, with input reversed polarity protection (if speaker's real power is large enough, the recommended DC power supply is 32V, 8A or more. Too small power would cause distortion or staccato to lose the shock effect)
Applicable speaker impedance: 4 ohm, 6 ohm, 8 ohm
Cooling: temperature controlled forced air cooling(the fan will automatically work to force cooling when the heat sink temperature is hot enough)
Four fixed gain settings available: 29.6 dB, 33.1 dB, 35.6 dB and 35.6dB
With standby and mute features
High efficiency: 85%

Description:
The TDA7498E is a 160W+160W dual-BTL class-D audio amplifier with single power supply designed for home theater and active speaker applications. It adopts 36-pin PowerSSO packaging with exposed pad up (EPU), more convenient to mount a separate heatsink.

Package Includes:
1 x TDA7498E Amplifier Board

title: Radial Fan 50mm Front- / Top-Part of Housing

description.text:
On my Anet A8 the front plastic part of the radial-fan broke on a screw. Even if a new fan does not cost much, I decided to rebuild this part.

Relatively quickly I found here a "dummy" of the fan: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1576438 From this massively designed part, I took the profile to build up on the top.

After a few tries it now fits quite well and the fan therefore also has a comparable rate as the original. I left The small clamps, which hold together the front and rear parts in the original. The shells now held in position by the two screws, as well as by a strip of adhesive tape. The tape also seals the remaining gap.

EDIT: I forgot to mention that the original combination of fan and nozzle did not hold correctly. So I had already before, as now with the self-printed parts, both to 2,5mm drill through and the parts with an M3 screws connected to each other.

title: MakerBot Cupcake Heated Build Platform v2.0

description.text:
This is a new and improved heated build platform. It is lightweight, compact, lower cost, and sexier than the old heated platform. It is also easier to put together and simpler in construction. The major breakthrough on this board is twofold:
  • We use a PCB for both the heater element and the support circuitry.
  • We use a lasercut aluminum heat spreader for uniform temperature.
    • After a bit of trial and error, we came up with an optimum trace resistance of about 4.5 ohms which gives us a 30 watt heater at 12v. This allows us to get up to 100C pretty easily (under 10 minutes).

Support open source 3D printing research and development by buying it from MakerBot at http://store.makerbot.com/cupcake-cnc/makerbot-cupcake-heated-build-platform-v2-0.html Full instructions are on the MakerBot wiki: http://wiki.makerbot.com/cchb1 We are also going to try something new with this project. We're going to use our forums for support. Here's the forum for this project: http://wiki.makerbot.com/forum/t-229036/makerbot-cupcake-heated-build-platform-v2-0#post-731781

comments.text: what is the difference with the original one and this one
comments.author: mraza123

comments.text: I love how simple this was to assemble, but I have a couple of comments that might make sense for the next revision.  Can you countersink the aluminum plate an include M3x16 flat head screws, plus washers and split washers?  That's how I ended up modding my HBP.  Also, I think a nice change to the PCB would involve changing the 3 pin connector to 0.1" spacing.  This way, we can take a 3 pin SIP header and solder it to the board (as well as the power connection, which I think is already 0.1").  Now if a wire ever fails, instead of disassembling everything, you just have to unplug the wire and recrimp new ones.  I guess some people hate crimp connectors, but if you have the tools, it's way easier.  :)
comments.author: dmatsumoto

comments.text: I taped on double stick carpet tape purchased from Walmart.  The tape has a cloth fiber backing. The tape's adhesive melts on the heated build platform and forms a flat sticky surface that the ABS adheres to.  There is no problem pulling off any object because the surface is still wet and sticky.  The heat keeps it from drying up.  After multiple uses the adhesive eventually gets overcooked and dry up.  So I just replace it.

People complain about the thin walls. Yes they are thin, but these little boxes come out great on my DaVinci Pro. I added some support pads to the upper rear side to match the pads in the front. They stack very nice but it is harder to get the tray out.

My printer sits on a small wire rack cart. I made the holders to clip on the side of a cart shelf, and it will hold a bin box. I have 3 sizes of clips. On my bottom shelf there is a double row on the bottom. This one measures 32mm outside width. My top shelf measure 27mm. I have another wire rack shelf that measures 30mm. I made all 3 brackets.

I removed the handle from the tray. I included both styles.

I made 2 lids for the bin boxes. One is smooth and flat. It has a cut out in the back to accommodate the holder. The other one will let you stack another bin box on top of it. Basically, it's a 13mm tall bin box. No cut out on this one.

description.text:
Beware, it's still a work in progress! I won't be able to try all parts now, but should fit nicely.
I had to think about a way to safely block access to hot and moving parts! Should also work to have a temperature controlled environment.

The hinges should be mounted on the frame, the same way as the top and bottom part: 1xM6x10mm screw and nut.

For the opening panels, the lock bar should be mounted with 2xM6 nut and bolts, while the rotating part should be mounted on the panel (M4 bolts).

If you want to have a fixed panel, just mount the bracket with 2xM6 nuts and bolts on the frame, and then on the panel (M4 bolts).

The other parts should be mounted on a polycarbonate panel, with the following dimensions: 29x75cm, 1/1,5 mm thickness (WARNING: check dimensions on all sides of your printer, as they may slighty vary beacuse of assembly: gap between the beams, and from the bed to the top parts of the frame). Thicker panels might be unable to close fully.

author: mtuieee

description.text: Batman - Wayne Enterprises logo

This is a little figurine that my 8 year old daughter Violet and I spent a Sunday afternoon making. My daughter drew a sketch, and I helped her translate it into Rhino. We printed it about 5 inches tall. The design is inspired by the principles in a book she read on Kawaii figure styles, but my daughter tells me that it's not a doll or model of any particular character.

I'm including a copy of the original Rhino file to help with remixing!

Her story (as told to me by Violet): Valentina is a princess of Japan, but she wants to be a magic user. Her parents disagree. She has already mastered the ability to fly, which comes in handy while trying to sneak out of her room at night. Her name is Valentina because she was born on Valentine's day.

PLA layer 0.10mm
Support @ 60º (simplify3D)

O material utilizado na impressão dessa cantoneira foi PLA.

Materiais para montagem

Para montar a grade de proteção você precisará de abraçadeiras de plástico, tubos de PVC com 25 mm de medida externa (tubo 3/4 de polegada de medida interna) e a tela, que pode ser de plástico ou de metal. Você pode substituir os tubos de PVC por cabos de vassoura.
Para montar com os tubos de PVC você deverá esquentar as pontas do tubo para fazê-las encaixar na cantoneira. Não é necessário utilizar cola, mas caso queira, poderá utilizar adesivo plástico, daqueles utilizados em encanamentos.

title: Toothbrush Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a holder for Spinbrush toothbrushes. Spinbrush has a flat bottom and can stand on its own, however the problem with all vertically stored toothbrushes is that after using them the last drops of the water flow down the handle of the toothbrush and make spots on the counter-top surface. In addition, electric toothbrushes have on/off switch which eventually gets clogged with dried remains of water and tooth paste mix.

To address aforementioned issues I designed this Spinbrush stand. It holds toothbrush in such a position that water remains drip off directly into small reservoir. The only downside of such way of storing toothbrush is - it takes more counter-top space.

title: Cat Food Shelf - holds 1.2L (5 cups) Rubbermaid container

description.text:
My house cats only eat dry food and frequently want a treat. Since the storage container did not have an easy-to-reach location, I designed this shelf in Tinkercad from scratch. It works well since it is the exact size needed and was mounted on the wall high enough to keep cats away, but easily within my reach.

The design was edited three times to add structure. Version 3 is the printed final product.

If you need more support for additional weight, re-print and mount upside-down under the original shelf or print the support stl. Works well with the same nice design.

The stl file with the square in the middle is meant to be mounted upside-down under the original shelf if the shelf needs to hold really heavy object.

Calibration tool for monoprice maker select.
Attaches to bearing from back with
2 m4 x 25 mm screws.
Add a dial indicator and it will help with leveling z axis and bed.
m3 x 12 screw and nut to tighten dial indicator into place

To level z axis.

  1. Lower bed completely in all 4 corners.
  2. Home z axis
  3. Measure height closest to z limit switch(home position.
  4. Move carriage to opposite side compare measurement to home position.
  5. Adjust lead screw to make values equal.
  6. Move carriage back to home position
  7. Recheck value (this will change when adjusting opposite side)
  8. Readjust as in steps 4-8 until values are equal even after adjustment.
    My results are consistently within .001
    I use octoprint to move carriage back and forth.
    Without I would grab the belt to move the carriage.

See link for more info

http://imgur.com/a/Qm6pf

description.text:
This are some foot dampers for the TRIUM 3D printer. They help to reduce the overall noise of the machine and reduce vibrations.

You will need to cut and add some anti-noise bumpers for washing machines. I bought ones from my local hardware store that cost around 5,5€ and I have only used 40% of them.

See Updates below

This holds a standard 1lb spool of solder. Compartment in the back for storing tweezers and side cutters.

The compartment in the back has large chamfers so that only one support is needed. I used S3D with support resolution set to 3mm to get one support column inside the rear compartment. This thing is printed on its side.

01/21/2017

Spool holder-v2 has been uploaded with the changes mentioned below added in. Printed it and I'm happy, I forsee no future changes. I wanted to get the stl out first, I'll add current pictures later.

01/17/2017

Fitment is perfect for the Kester spool I have on hand. If someone has a need for a larger size, please let me know in comments. I like everything about it so far:

  • The catch at the end does its purpose well, but doesn't make it hard to take spool on or off.
  • As shown in the newly upload pics, there isn't much clearance between spool and bottom but it does freely move. In fact, with a new 1lb spool the rod doesn't flex much at all (I printed first with PETG, will be using PLA for the next version) but if it did, it would "ride on the floor" below it.
  • Rear compartment fits flush cutter and tweezers well. I want to increase it's size to accommodate flux paste tube.

That said, I will be making a couple modifications over the next day.

  • Increasing the wall thickness of the rear compartment as well as the compartment's volume.
  • Raise the front edge to allow the feed hole to be a height that is halfway between a full spool and a nearly empty one.

Finally, I'm open to ideas but currently limited to 120x120x120mm print size. I'd also like to keep it simple in purpose and not too specific. The other holders I looked at before designing this one tried to either be the solution for everything, or too specific solution (e.g. you'd have to buy the same tweezer set as they had)

01/16/2017

I'm currently printing the thing, need to double check fitment once it is done. Will make modifications or remove this paragraph 01/17/2017 Eastern morning.

So I loosely remixed this off of teinturman's ring sizer. (Big thanks for all the data and country matching logic I borrowed from him)

In short, this is more a template I'll use later to make rings more customizable, and I'll clean up the code soon-ish. With school starting it'll be more of a wait and see.

update 1/16/17
Fixed integer sizes from being demoted from a string to an int, by casting sizeValue as a str where applicable.

update 1/20/17
Made the default ring better.

Once I clean up the code I'll explain more how it all works. In a nutshell, it goes through some if else blocks to decide which country you're in, then will call the ring() module and send it the ring's diameter if the size you selected works. Otherwise you'll just end up with a weird cylinder.

Beschreibung (DE):

Im Zuge des Airster Community Projekts habe ich eine Abdeckung für den Umbau einer FatShark Attitude v3 auf Diversity (Realacc RX5808 Lite) erstellt. Damit die Abdeckung nicht wie selbstgemacht aussieht, hab ich den 3D Printed Look mit Hilfe von Nassschleifpapier und Filler in der Postproduction entfernt.

Realacc RX5808 Lite

Made:

Made of PLA black (Verbatine)
Extruder temperature: 210°C
Glass bed temperature: 58°C
Resolution: 0.30 mm
Infill: 15%
Print speed: 50mm/s

0.3

15%

Vorarbeit:
Zuerst hab ich die Oberfläche mit Feilen und feinem Schleifpapier bearbeitet. Benutzt hab ich hier ein 640er Korn, damit alle groben Druckfehler egalisiert werden und zudem verringern wir damit die tiefe der Täler zwischen den einzelnen Drucklinien.

Fillern:
Als nächstes füllen wir alle kleinen Risse und Lücken mit Spritzspachtel auf. Diesen Vorgang hab ich 4 mal wiederholt bis man eine sehr glatte Oberfläche hat und man nach dem Fillern keine Drucklinien mehr sieht.

Tipp:
Beim Lackieren darauf achten dass man immer nur eine dünne Schichten Aufträgt. Ich hab es immer so gemacht dass ich nach ca. 5 Minuten wieder eine dünne Schicht aufgetragen habe und so konnte ich ca. 3 Schichten auf einmal auftragen und dieses hab ich 4 mal wiederholt.

Werkzeug:
Da wir hier nicht nur Rundungen haben sondern auch feine Ecken und eine Feile zu grob für diesen Job wäre. Hab ich mir schnell einen, ich nenne es jetzt mal “Schleifstift” gebastelt. So kommt man perfekt in die Ecken um eine saubere Kante zu erzeugen.

Finaler Schliff
Den finale Schliff hab ich mit einem 1000er Korn gemacht. Das ist für Schwarz Matte Oberflächen ausreichend. Beim letzten Schleifen nur noch ganz zart vorgehen um keine Kratzer oder Unebenheiten zu erzeugen.

Löcher
Die Löcher und Senkungen hab ich noch von der Spachtelmasse mit einem Senker befreit, da sonst die Schrauben nicht genug Platz haben.

Maßnehmen:
Der Einzige Weg die Form in die CAD Software zu bekommen war aus meiner Sicht das sukzessive rantasten an die Form der Brille. So vergingen mehrere Stunden damit kleine Muster zu drucken, anzuhalten und wieder nachzubessern.
Am Ende hatte ich die Grundform einigermaßen digitalisiert und konnte mit der Aussparung für das Modul beginnen. Auch hier wieder so lange mich rangetastet bis ich das gewünschte Design fertig hatte.

CAD Software:
Benutzt wurde die Software "onshape". Eine Full-Cloud CAD Browser Tool. Die Software ist Kostenlos mit der Möglichkeit auf einen Premiumaccount. Einfach und schnell zu lernen aber sehr viele Möglichkeiten die bei anderen CAD Systemen fehlen oder teuer sind.

title: Speed Racer Testbots
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
It's hard to find a better test print than the Ultimaker robot; it has insets, embossings, overhangs, bridges, posts, and fine features, all wrapped up in a model that's less than an inch and a half tall. This Customizer lets you create a base for the robot which you can use to record all your slicer and printer settings.

We optimized Cura settings for speed printing by modifying layer height, wall and roof counts, infill density, print speed, and minimum layer time, then recorded those settings on bases and glued on the corresponding 3D printed robots.

These printed Speed Racer Testbots will help us share best practices and slicer information with students and faculty who use the 3D printers at JMU 3SPACE.

Read more at Hacktastic: mathgrrl.com/hacktastic/2017/01/slicer-testbot/

description.text:
We got these silicone faucet spouts to help our daughter use and reach the sink. Unfortunately the "universal" design wasn't so universal, and the silicone ring would not stay on the faucet aerator. The sink's aerator is a tad too narrow, and too small a diameter. So, I whipped up this little bushing thing, to give the faucet a little more gurth, and made a wider ring with a lip to ensure it stays on. Printed with PLA. The ring is a good pressure fit, nice and snug. ABS you may need to scale it up a couple % points due to shrinkage.

I don't know if these aerators are a common size, mine measured 24mm diameter.
I can tweak it with the diameter of your aerator if need be.
